data.title: Good Asian Food
data.text: It appears the a good portion of the Asian community enjoys their meals here.  It must be reasonable authentic.  It's always busy!

data.title: Go for the Dim Sum, not the environment.
data.text:
The Eastern Pearl serves Dim Sum daily and not just weekends. 

They come by with the carts and you can select your dishes. We requested a steamed pork bun which they subsequently brought. 

We enjoyed the selection and taste of the dishes we tried. 

The restaurant is larger than it looks with tables in front and a dining area in the back. Environment is basic but definitely worth a visit if you enjoy Dim Sum.

data.title: Not up to normal excellence
data.text:
Went there for lunch and even with it half full, service was  very slow and late. We're seated in the back room, felt like the 3 tables were ignored with no carts came in for 10 mins. One couple left due to this. The cart was less than full without the  normal selections. 
What we got was good, just waited way too long.

data.title: Excellent first meal here
data.text:
We went in the middle of the afternoon on a rainy Sunday, so things were pretty quiet, but the service was quick and the food was all freshly prepared. We started with hot and sour soup - great flavor, although no tree ear mushrooms or shitaake.

We split three dim sum orders one entry and some house special fried rice and have leftovers that will make another small meal. The juicy pork dumplings were flavored with five spice and very tender. The shrimp and leek dumplings were very tasty but not "wow". The scallion pancakes had good flavor but were a bit too greasy.

The house special fried rice had been freshly prepared and had big pieces of tender beef, chicken and juicy (large) shrimp - very good. We ordered General Tso's chicken because I've never had it (in spite of many Chinese meals) and it was very good. Chicken coating was crispy and the sauce was tart-sweet, so not cloying or sugary.

We'll definitely be back to try more things from the menu

data.title: Great Weekend Dim sum
data.text: I've never visited during the weekday.  We always visit on the weekend when they serve dim sum.  The dim sum is high quality and the servers are very friendly.

data.title: Home made Hakka Dim Sum.
data.text:
The local home made Dim Sum is by far, the best in the Seattle area. Even the 80/20% ratio. Is right on. Arrived early and was worried mostly non Asian. But as it got closer to Noon... The locals started to fill in. They have 2 dining rooms, the front room is what you see from the street. Seeing the line outside, see the front room, newbies turn around and leave. The BACK room is double the size of the front. So, if you see a line, not too long a wait. 
The food is worth it. The steamer rolls around frequently, deep fried of pan fried, done when ordered. Fresh hot and tasty. 
Worth the wait.

data.title: Great pot-stickers to go
data.text: Stopped in with my niece to take something back for the Christmas / wedding guests at the house. Ordered two order of pot-stickers and was welcomed to sit and have tea while we waited. Took them back and everyone loved them. Next time I'll make sure to go there for a sit down meal.

data.title: Truly a great Dim Sum place in Redmond.
data.text:
Today we found a new Dim Sum place to call the Best of Redmond/ East side. The Standard Fare, haw gow, shu mai, fun gow and steamed spare ribs have tasted the best ever in the Seattle Area
 The ethnic percentage is 98% Asian to 2% other. A great %.

data.title: Flavorful & Exotic
data.text: Cantonese, Sichuan, Hunan ... these are the cuisines we know, but what about Hakka?  This nomadic Chinese people developed a wonderful style of cooking all their own, very zesty without reliance on hot spice although you can get that too.  Lots of pepper, salt, fresh vegetables, good meats in dim sum, chewy dough dumplings, pickled cabbage, pea vines, yum!  We started with a flavorful hot 'n sour soup, missed the black tree fungus but otherwise excellent - certainly didn't miss the MSG (they don't use it).  Then the yellow-orange veggie potstickers - dough infused with carrots - double yum!  Our main course was #19 Stir Fried Hakka Style Shrimp with Vegetables.  Good big chunks of broccoli and snow peas, good quality medium tailless veined shrimp infused with garlic and red pepper, and secret ingredients blended to perfection.  Also had Sichuan green beans which were Hakka'd with the pickled cabbage and nice and spicy.  Added dim sum - shrimp dumplings, which were in the most delicate wrappings and delectable, and the Juicy Pork dumplings which were in very light dough (as opposed to the chewy fried dough of the potstickers), with bits of savory pork inside, but not overwhelmingly meaty (which I prefer).  Ended with a dessert of creme brûlée with a crackle top that would have done any French chef proud.  This place looks like nothing on the outside, but is everything you'd want in a great Chinese restaurant - comfy, unpretentious, cheap, huge menu, great food.

data.title: Pretty tasty Chinese food in heart of Redmond
data.text: Street parking can be scarce but Eastern Pearl will pay your parking lot fee if you dine there which is a nice bonus.  Some dishes were a hit and some were a miss.  I always look for Beef Chow Fun on every Chinese menu and compare it to what I had growing up in NYC.  Eastern Pearl's was a little bland and not as dry a version as I would prefer. Their crispy orange beef had good flavor but I was disappointed that the deep fried beef chunks got soggy  so quickly under the sauce.  The Singapore Rice Noodles was spot on delicious and the Szechuan chicken was very fresh and tasty.  Menu is extensive and the first two dishes I reviewed might be the Hakka version of the dishes.  Make no mistake, we will come back because the food is good and the prices are good as well.  Service was excellent as well and the owner was very attentive and funny.

data.title: Great Menu Not so Great Food
data.text:
We were really in the mood for Chinese food the other night and decided to try the place closest to home.  The menu is great with lots of items that are not on the typical Chinese menu.  

The sad news is most of the food was not too great. The spring rolls and fried rice were average.  The orange beef and chow main were much worse the average.

The pork knuckles were so poor we barely touched them which is a shame.

Both my wife and I woke up with intestinal issues that we cannot for sure blame on the food but it is not the kind of circumstantial evidence that encourages you to go back for sure...

data.title: Average at best
data.text: The food was not impressive, either in looks or flavor.  It was not bad food, but it did not inspire.

data.title: great chinese food
data.text: We went for lunch and just ordered family style dinner B came with soup, vegetable egg roll, pot stickers, pork fried rice, honey pecan prawns,sweet and sour chicken and chicken with vegetables, it was all good.Had the left overs for dinner the next day and food was still was very good. we will return. It is very hard to find excellent Chinese food.

data.title: Good food
data.text:
I came across this restaurant when searching on Trip Advisor. Its of pretty good rating so I decided to try it.  

The restaurant serves both authentic and good american Chinese food. It seats about 50 people and was good for a small business. I was there for dinner and will definitely return for dim sum another day

data.title: This the best Chinese food in the Redmond area. Charlie is the owner and is a wonderful host.
data.text: I love the food. It is good Mandarin Chinese food. The soup is great and the tea is better than any I have had. Plenty for two or more. Or even better for next day lunch.

data.title: great local Chinese
data.text: We ordered and took out from this restaurant, it was close to our hotel location but still had to drive and park which was a challenge given the streets all being torn up with repaving work. The items we ordered were well done and rather large portions but we did find the garlic was quite heavy in some of the dishes.  Great pricing and items were ready as promissed

data.title: good dim sum!
data.text:
Heard about this restaurant(東江樓) specialized in Hakka (客家菜) cuisine, so when we visited Seattle that weekend we went not having any specific Hakka cuisine in mind. It’s packed.
Surprised was that they actually served dim sum that noon, we certainly had some and they were GOOD. Baked Wheat Cake燒餅 Chinese Doughnut油條, a Chinese/Taiwanese favorite, also served. (But we did not take it). Sticky Rice Dumplings 粽子 are popular too, the one we want, with meat, sold out.
We also ordered  Braised Pork with Rice 台式魯肉飯 , which was a failure, without true taste of Taiwanese rice with pork (the owner explained that the chef did not know how to do it right even he taught him how to) ; Pan Fried Scallion Pancake 蔥油餅 ,which was too dry, not much tasty. 
This restaurant was plain and modest in and out. Service was good though. The owner was really friendly.

data.title: Best Chinese food on the east side
data.text: The Chinese food in this area is pretty unreliable so I was very excited to come across this place. It's comfortable and clean inside. The staff are friendly and the service is quick. All of our food was fresh and delicately seasoned. Such a nice relief from the salty over-soy sauced fare we usually find. Reasonably priced, definitely worth it if you are on the east side.

data.title: Great value for good food
data.text: My husband and I always eat here after shopping at the nearby Redmond Town Center. The bills always total in the $20s, with leftover to bring home. Great value for the quality and taste of the food. The owner is very friendly and tends to your requests very fast. The staff, however, is a bit slack when the boss is not around. Hence the missing star.

data.title: Food's not bad, atmosphere is neat
data.text: Branded as Chinese Hakka restaurant, they whip up pretty decent standard fare.  I frequent here as a post work out meal.  Proprietor makes for light humourous conversation, too.
